issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
I tried with:
Resources within this scaling group
Image ID
Instance type

None of those options populated the dimension field for the alarm that was created.
fields.summary: Create alarm dialog is not properly passing along dimension information

comments.body:
Yep, not finding code in the Alarm model where it should set the Dimension.member.N param

To be clear, in the PutMetricAlarm call, we should supply (for example);
Dimension.member.1.Name=ThisScalingGroupName
Dimension.member.1.Value=mytestgroup

??

I want to point out that the alarm.js model does not send any Dimension params in the request. The proxy handles a list of dimensions, but probably not properly. Feel free to pull me in if you need help once we decide that exact params that need to be sent / received.
[~dkavanagh] - Sounds like we're going to need a widget for adding/removing to a collection of dimensions, instead of just one value like we have in the UI now, eh?
I thought we "should" be able to specify a list of dimensions, but I wondered if [~jloza] wanted to keep the UX simpler by only dealing with a single dimension per alarm.
one dimension per metric to keep it simple. One metric per alarm.

Okay, implemented that far, with additional stuff for switching to lists later. 
[~dkavanagh] - I'm sending in these params:

Dimensions.member.1.Name:ThisScalingGroupName
Dimensions.member.1.Value:MonsterJoeTruckAndTow

Need the proxy modification too before this one can be closed. Want me to look at it?

Here's the fix so far, in a EUCA-7906 branch. Pull request deferred until proxy work is ready:
https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus-console/commit/5bbce6556bda
I'll check it out. I can get it going pretty soon, I think.

I've added an alarm. request params were;
AlarmName	test7906
ComparisonOperator	GreaterThanThreshold
Dimensions.member.1.Name	ThisScalingGroupName
Dimensions.member.1.Value	daktest-sg
EvaluationPeriods	2
MetricName	GroupDesiredCapacity
Namespace	AWS/AutoScaling
Period	60
Statistic	Average
Threshold	1
_xsrf	dae77169ec804d8b97c2fc07479bec1e

Reading it back via euca2ools
test7906	INSUFFICIENT_DATA		AWS/AutoScaling	GroupDesiredCapacity	60	Average	2	GreaterThanThreshold	1.0

Reading back with --debug, I see the dimension in the XML!

I think that works. Now, when I save the alarm using the Dimensions.member.N attributes, the updated alarm from the proxy has a populated 'dimensions' object in it:
{
dimensions: Object
ThisScalingGroupName: Array[1]
0: "MonsterJoeTruckAndTow"
length: 1
__proto__: Array[0]
__proto__: Object
}
It's in kind of a weird looking form, but maybe there are possible name/value combinations in which the values are arrays? We can work with this though. Thanks.
AWS docs call for a string in both name and value... the array doesn't really make sense there.  Is that a boto thing?

[~jpommer]
Looks like boto uses a dict:

In [7]: metric.dimensions
Out[7]: {}

Added another commit to the branch - the model's parse() function - to deal with incoming dimensions object as it is, and still work with it later if it turns out the value part needs to be changed to a string instead of an array.

Yes, "dimensions": {"ThisScalingGroupName": ["daktest-sg"]} is the form that boto uses. It handles the case of multiple values per name by treating those each unique pair as a different dimension. This form is just more efficient than listing the name each time for different values.

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus-console/pull/168

In what case would there be more than one value for a key? You can't set more than one Value to a Name in the request:

Dimensions.member.1.Name = ThisScalingGroupName
Dimensions.member.1.Value = One
Dimension.member.2.Name = ThisScalingGroupName
Dimensions.member.2.Value = Two

I'd expect that to overwrite the first one.
I've added two polices to a scaling group. After that I was able to see those polices via UI and CLT.
